awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 ACM/IEEE International Conference on Nanoscale Computing and Communication (ACM/IEEE NanoCom)
awd_abstract_narration:
The ACM/IEEE NanoCom conference series aims at creating a trans-disciplinary forum to foster and develop new communications and computing paradigms for nanoscale machines. The conference has been held annually since 2014 and has become the premier venue for fundamental advances in nanoscale computing and communication networks.  NanoCom highlights research potentials, stimulates novel and breakthrough ideas, and identifies the short and medium-term exploitation goals. The conference features distinguished keynote speakers, invited plenary talks and an open call for papers presented both in oral and poster sessions. Novel theoretical research results, implementation-based solutions, and position and roadmap papers are welcome.

This award will support 10 students in the United States to attend ACM/IEEE NanoCom 2019, which will be held in Dublin, Ireland, on September 25-27, 2019. Attending such high-caliber technical venue is extremely valuable for future researchers. This is a truly inter-disciplinary field, which requires close interaction and frequent discussions with experts that span different areas. ACM/IEEE NanoCom 2019 is aimed at becoming the forum for such discussions to occur. Students will not only be exposed to the state-of-the-art in the field, but they will also have the opportunity to interact with peers from institutions worldwide, meet with leading researchers, and take part in discussions that are likely to shape the future of the field. The travel grants will target undergraduate and graduate students who will substantially benefit from attending this conference but have limited travel funds. In particular, one quarter of the available awards will be reserved to first-time attendees to NanoCom who do not have a paper accepted to the conference, with priority to undergraduate and first-year graduate students. Another quarter of the available awards will be reserved for under-represented groups (women, minorities and people with disabilities), with or without an accepted paper. For the remaining half of the available awards (not reserved for the aforementioned categories), higher priority will be given to female students as well as those from underrepresented minority-serving institutions that are not traditionally represented in the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to provide U.S.-based graduate students conducting research in nanoscale computing and communication with the opportunity to attend the ACM NanoCom conference. NSF support was used to cover most travel and registration expenses for approximately 10 students. Attending high-caliber technical conferences like ACM NanoCom is invaluable for emerging researchers. Nanonetworking is an interdisciplinary field requiring collaboration and discussions across diverse expertise. ACM NanoCom provides a forum for such interactions, exposing students to cutting-edge research, fostering peer connections, and enabling discussions that shape the future of the field.

 

This project prioritized inclusivity and diversity by reserving funds for first-time attendees, underrepresented groups (including women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities), and students from minority-serving institutions. The funding distribution was as follows: (i) 25% of awards were reserved for first-time attendees without an accepted paper, with priority given to undergraduate and first-year graduate students; (ii) 25% were reserved for underrepresented groups, regardless of paper acceptance; and (iii) the remaining 50% prioritized female students and students from underrepresented institutions. This prioritization was explicitly announced in the student travel grant program advertisements.

 

Over the life of the grant:

  1. Year 1: Five travel grants were awarded, including three to women, one to a member of the Cherokee Nation, and four to first-time participants (three without accepted papers).
  2. Year 2: Due to the virtual format of the conference, travel grants were not offered. Instead, funds were used to reimburse students' registration fees to cover publication costs. Five awards were granted, all to first-time participants, one without an accepted paper.
  3. Year 3: Similar to Year 2, virtual participation led to reimbursement of registration fees, with five awards granted to first-time participants, one without an accepted paper.
  4. Year 4: Four travel grants were awarded, all to first-time participants without accepted papers.
  5. Year 5: Two final travel grants were awarded, compatible with funding availability after the no-cost extensions.

 

All awardees actively participated in the respective ACM NanoCom conferences. Those with accepted papers or posters presented their work, and all were recognized during the closing remarks or awards ceremony.

 

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

This project integrated research and education by supporting students’ participation in a premier technical conference. Attendees engaged with cutting-edge research, interacted with leading researchers, and participated in interdisciplinary discussions spanning computer science, engineering, nanotechnology, and the physical sciences. These opportunities enhanced students’ understanding of nanoscale computing and communication and allowed them to contribute to and learn from innovative discussions, broadening their perspectives and potentially shaping their future research directions.

 

Broader Impact Outcomes:

This project increased diversity in STEM by enabling students from underrepresented groups to attend a prestigious conference. Students benefited from exposure to state-of-the-art research and networking opportunities, fostering collaborations and career development. The research community, in turn, benefited from the inclusion of new perspectives and the development of a more diverse pipeline of researchers. The interdisciplinary nature of ACM NanoCom, which brings together experts in fields ranging from computer science and engineering to biology and materials science, provided a transformative learning experience. This dynamic environment encouraged cross-disciplinary dialogue and the generation of innovative research ideas. By supporting these students, the project advanced NSF’s mission of broadening participation in STEM and strengthening the next generation of researchers.

This project exemplifies how targeted support for student participation in premier technical venues can enhance diversity, foster interdisciplinary research, and prepare future leaders in nanoscale computing and communication.
